Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

(2) Summary

API Governance becomes increasingly challenging with increasing organizational size: How to best balance the needs of faster and more agile ways of developing products with the overarching needs of the organization? The first pillar of API Governance are insights: In order to understand where the API landscape is moving, it is important to understand what it looks like. APIs take the radical stance of making implementations opaque, which means that the only truly API-compatible way of gaining insights into an API landscape is through its APIs. The second pillar of API Governance are interfaces: Enterprise architecture often mixes concerns of what to build, and how to build it. APIs are a departure from this model by saying that how things are built is of no concern to a capability's user, but that what is being built can make a big difference in terms of how APIs are discovered and used. The third pillar of API Governance is nudging: The most effective way to evolve API landscapes is when teams make all the right design and implementation decisions (from the organization's point of view) by themselves. By helping teams with support and tooling, platform teams have great influence on what teams perceive as the best way to design and build their products. Using these three pillars of API governance, enterprise architects and platform teams can have a substantial and productive influence on an organization's API landscape. In this session we discuss issues such as how to create and manage API guidelines, and how to establish and execute an API program.

From Building Systems to Designing Ecosystems Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

(8) API Architecture 101

  • You know what products teams are delivering but not how they are producing them
  • There can be no hidden dependencies between products
  • Delivery velocity increases because teams can pick tools and can move at their own speed
  • Consumers satisfaction increases because products get released and changed more quickly


From Building Systems to Designing Ecosystems Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

(9) API Governance 101

  • Minimizing constraints maximizes team autonomy and thus productivity
  • Coherence across products must be managed
  • Identifying and supporting cross-product concerns increases landscape productivity
  • Building openness and robustness into the landscape is critical

(11) API Visibility: Inside-Out vs. Outside-In



Insights: API the APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

(12) API Descriptions: Labeling APIs [http://dret.net/lectures/api-days-paris-2019/]

  • APIs can be described in a variety of ways
    • Technical descriptions for interface mechanics (e.g., OpenAPI [https://www.openapis.org/] and AsyncAPI [https://www.asyncapi.com/])
    • Documentation intended for human consumption
    • Metadata helping with API lifecycle management (e.g., APIs.json [http://apisjson.org/] and schema.org [https://schema.org/WebAPI])
  • API description requirements
    • Be independent of API technology and implementation
    • Define an evolving set of well-known elements
    • Provide openness for custom additions
    • Support existing formats for backwards-compatibility
    • Build on existing patterns and specifications for description on the Web


Insights: API the APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

Interfaces: What over How Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

(16) Constraints > Rules

  • Aim for the minimal number of constraints for your API landscape
    • Minimizing constraints maximizes the freedom of teams
    • Revisit existing constraints and remove/relax them when possible
  • Look at rules at suggestions how to satisfy constraints
    • Help teams to satisfy constraints if they want/need help
    • Try to make rules optional whenever possible


Interfaces: What over How Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

(17) APIs for Loose Coupling

  • Teams communicate through their API dependencies
    • Avoid hidden dependencies like shared libraries
  • There are no shortcuts: APIs are the only way to create dependencies
    • API stories help with the design of product APIs
  • Implementation details and concerns are never made visible
    • Implementation changes can be done safely

(19) Nudging in Ecosystems



Nudging: Engineering the Engineers Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

(20) The API Landscaper's Job

  • Realizing the promise of becoming better at changing
    1. Increase time to value when making value chain changes
    2. Decrease dependencies between value chain building blocks
    3. Improve effectiveness of API teams at the organizational level
  • Observing and connecting teams to improve their productivity
    1. Create open and visible value chains
    2. Remove hidden dependencies
    3. Provide a platform for effective API product teams

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging

(22) Embrace the Ecosystem

  • Insights: Decide what you need to see
  • Interfaces: Separate the what from the how
  • Nudging: Use constraints/incentives to control the ecosystem


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Mastering API Governance with Insights, Interfaces, and Nudging
